Pique Turn.definition: a movement performed in the passé position while turning to the inside and  usually done in a series.

instructions: Begin with your feet in first position, heels touching and toes pointing outward.
Transfer your weight to your left foot and lift your right foot off the ground, pointing your toe and bringing it to the back of your left ankle.
Push off your left foot and lift your right leg into a passé position, bringing your foot to the front of your left knee.
As you turn, pivot on your left foot and bring your right leg around to the front in a pique position.
As you complete the turn, land on your right foot with your left foot in a pique position.
exercises: Tendus with 10 repetition on each side
Passe releves with 10 repetitions on each side
amateur.tip: When practicing pique turns, it is a good idea to start with your stronger side and then move on to your weaker side.

instructions: Begin with your feet in first position, heels touching and toes pointing outward. Evenly distribute the weight between your feet and core muscles for balance and control.

Prepare for the turn by lifting your back foot into a pique position, bringing it to the back of your supporting ankle. Hold this position firmly and securely, and make sure your weight is centered over your supporting foot.

Use your supporting leg to initiate the turn by pushing off the ground and lifting your pique foot into a passe position in front of your knee. Keep your core muscles engaged and your arms in a comfortable position for balance and control.

As you turn, pivot on your supporting leg and bring your pique foot around to the front, pointing your toes and keeping your leg straight. Keep your eyes focused on a fixed point in front of you to help with spotting, and use your core muscles to help you maintain your balance and control throughout the turn.
Complete the turn by landing on your supporting leg with your pique foot still in front of your knee.
exercises: Plie variations: Try doing grand plies in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as demi-plies with various arm positions.
Releves variations: Single-leg, double-legs in first, second and fifth positions, releve passé
Spotting exercises: Doing half-turns or full turns with a focus on spotting
intermediate.tip: As you become more comfortable with the movement, you can experiment with different arm positions and try multiple turns in a row to challenge yourself.

instructions: Start with your feet in first position, with your heels touching and your toes turned out. Make sure your weight is evenly distributed between both feet and your core muscles are engaged to help with balance and control.

Prepare for the turn by lifting your back foot into a pique position, bringing it to the back of your supporting ankle. Hold this position firmly and securely, and make sure your weight is centered over your supporting foot.

Use your supporting leg to initiate the turn by pushing off the ground and lifting your pique foot into a passe position in front of your knee. Keep your core muscles engaged and your arms in a comfortable position for balance and control.

As you turn, pivot on your supporting leg and bring your pique foot around to the front, pointing your toes and keeping your leg straight. Keep your eyes focused on a fixed point in front of you to help with spotting, and use your core muscles to help you maintain your balance and control throughout the turn.

Complete the turn by landing on your supporting leg with your pique foot still in front of your knee. To challenge yourself, try doing multiple turns in a row and experiment with different arm positions.
exercises: Plie variations: To warm up your legs and improve your turnout, try doing grand plies in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as demi-plies with various arm positions.

Releve variations: Work on strengthening your calves and ankles with releve exercises. Try doing single-leg and double-leg releves in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as releve passe exercises to help prepare for the pique turn.
Arabesque balances: Work on improving your balance and control by practicing arabesque balances. Start with a low arabesque and gradually work your way up to a higher arabesque position.

Spotting exercises: Practicing spotting exercises can help improve your balance and control during the pique turn. Try doing half-turns or full turns with a focus on spotting, and gradually increase the speed and difficulty of the turns.

Flexibility stretching: Stretch out your muscles before practicing pique turns to help prevent injury and improve your flexibility. Focus on stretching your legs, hips, and back, and incorporate stretches for your shoulders and arms as well.

stability: Plank holds: Start with a standard plank hold for 30 seconds, then progress to side plank holds and plank variations such as mountain climbers and plank jacks.
Single-leg balance: Practice balancing on one leg, with arms in different positions to challenge yourself. You can also try adding in arm or leg movements while maintaining your balance.

Bosu ball balance: Use a Bosu ball to work on your stability and balance. Stand on the flat side of the ball and try different balance exercises, such as standing on one leg, squatting, or doing lunges.
flexibility: Pigeon pose: Stretch your hips and glutes with pigeon pose. Hold the pose for 30 seconds on each side, and try different variations to increase the stretch.

Forward fold: Stretch your hamstrings and lower back with a forward fold. Hold the pose for 30 seconds and try different variations, such as grabbing onto your ankles or using a yoga block for support.

Downward-facing dog: Stretch your shoulders, hamstrings, and calves with downward-facing dog. Hold the pose for 30 seconds and try different variations, such as pedaling your feet or lifting one leg up at a time.
coordination: Pirouette with arms: Practice turning with different arm positions to improve your coordination. Start with simple arm positions and gradually increase the difficulty.
Spotting practice: Improve your spotting technique by practicing half and full turns with a focus on spotting. Gradually increase the speed and difficulty of the turns.
Quick footwork patterns: Improve your coordination and footwork by practicing quick combinations, such as chasses, sissonnes, and pas de bourrees.
artistry: Flowing port de bras: Work on your port de bras by practicing flowing arm movements, focusing on making smooth transitions and expressive gestures.
Dance to different music: Explore different styles of music and try dancing to each one, focusing on expressing the mood and emotion of the music through your movements.
Free movement improvisation: Let your body move freely and spontaneously, without any set choreography. Focus on expressing yourself through movement and exploring different levels and dynamics.

low: 3 repetitions on each side for 5 minutes
medium: 5 repetitions on each side for 10 minutes

Fish Roll and Flop.definition: a movement where the dancer rolls their body in a fluid motion resembling the movement of a fish, while the Flop is a contemporary dance move where the dancer falls to the ground in a sudden and dramatic manner.

instructions: Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart.
Lift your right shoulder up and back, simultaneously lifting your left shoulder up and forward.
Move your right shoulder down and forward, then move your left shoulder down and back, alternating continuously.
Focus on maintaining proper form and control throughout the movement.
Practice regularly to improve your technique and coordination.
exercises: Shoulder shrugs: Stand with your arms at your sides and your shoulders relaxed. Shrug your shoulders up towards your ears, hold for a few seconds, then release and lower them back down.

Arm circles: Stand with your arms extended out to the sides, parallel to the ground. Begin making circular motions with your arms, first small and gradually increasing the size of the circles. Repeat in the opposite direction.

Cat-cow stretch: Begin on your hands and knees, with your wrists under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Arch your back and tuck your chin towards your chest, then release and let your belly drop towards the ground, lifting your head and tailbone towards the ceiling.
amateur.tip: Make sure to start with gentle warm-up exercises that target major muscle groups and gradually increase in intensity to help prepare your body for more strenuous activity.

instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart and engage your core muscles for stability.
Lift right shoulder up and back.
Simultaneously lift left shoulder up and forward.
Move right shoulder down and forward.
Move left shoulder down and back, alternating continuously.
exercises: Cross-body shoulder stretch: Sit or stand with your feet hip-width apart. Reach one arm across your body, using your other arm to gently pull it towards your chest. Hold for 10-20 seconds, then switch sides.
Thread the needle stretch: Begin on your hands and knees, then thread one arm through the space between your opposite arm and knee. Hold for 10-20 seconds, then switch sides.

Reverse table-top pose: Sit on the ground with your hands behind you and your feet on the ground. Lift your hips up towards the ceiling, creating a table-top shape with your body. Hold for 10-20 seconds, then release.

instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart and engage your core muscles for stability.
Lift both shoulders up, then rotate them back, down, and forward in a fluid motion.
Increase the speed and fluidity of the movement, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout.
Incorporate other upper body movements, such as arm circles, to challenge yourself.
Practice regularly to improve your technique and coordination.
exercises: Yoga dolphin pose: Begin on your hands and knees, then lift your hips up and press your hands and forearms into the ground. Hold for 10-20 seconds, then release.
Handstand preparation: Practice handstand preparation exercises, such as kicking up against a wall or using a partner for support.
Pilates swan dive: Lie on your stomach with your arms extended in front of you. Lift your arms, chest, and legs off the ground simultaneously, then release back down. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.

Axel Turn.definition: a jump in which the skater rotates 360 degrees in the air, landing on the back foot.

instructions: Start in B-plus position.
Swing arms forward and jump off back foot.
Rotate 360 degrees with legs crossed.
Land on the back foot.
Practice with a half turn first.
Begin in B-plus position.
Swing arms forward, then up into crossed position.
Jump off back foot, bringing legs into crossed position.
Rotate 360 degrees, maintaining crossed leg position.
Land on the back foot, bending knees to absorb impact.
Start in B-plus position.
Swing arms forward, then up into crossed position.
Jump off back foot, bringing legs into crossed position.
Rotate 540 degrees or more, maintaining crossed leg position.
Land on the back foot, bending knees to absorb impact.

Jazz Contraction.definition: a contraction of the muscles in the back of the legs, which is used to create a higher jump.

instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart.
Bend knees slightly.
Curve spine forward, contracting core.
Drop head down, keeping neck aligned.
Slowly return to starting position.
Stand with feet hip-width apart.
Bend knees, lowering into plié.
Curve spine forward, contracting core.
Drop head, maintaining neck alignment.
Add fluid arm movements for style.
Stand with feet hip-width apart.
Bend knees, lowering into deep plié.
Curve spine forward, engaging core.
Drop head, maintaining neck alignment.
Incorporate dynamic full-body movements.

Hitch Kick.definition: a jump in which the skater kicks the back leg forward, then lands on the front foot.

instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart.
Kick leading leg forward.
Hop on supporting leg.
Kick trailing leg forward.
Land on trailing leg, leading leg in front.
Stand with feet hip-width apart.
Kick leading leg forward, knee straight.
Hop on supporting leg, bending knee.
Kick trailing leg forward, knee straight.
Land on trailing leg, leading leg in front.
Stand with feet hip-width apart.
Kick leading leg forward, knee straight and high.
Hop on supporting leg, bending knee.
Kick trailing leg forward, knee straight and high.
Land on trailing leg, leading leg in front, maintaining balance.

Chaine Leaps.definition: a series of jumps in which the skater alternates between the front and back legs.

instructions: Start in B-plus position.
Perform a chaine turn.
Push off the back leg, leaping forward.
Land on the front leg, bending knees.
Repeat with the opposite leg.
Begin in B-plus position.
Perform a chaine turn, swinging arms.
Push off the back leg, leaping with straight legs.
Land on the front leg, bending knees.
Continue leaping with alternating legs.
Start in B-plus position.
Perform a chaine turn, swinging arms with precision.
Push off the back leg, leaping with high straight legs.
Land on the front leg, bending knees.
Flow seamlessly into the next chaine leap.
